article.headline: Miami 78, Wake Forest 69
article.story: CORAL GABLES, Fla. (AP) -- Robert Hite is on a roll. And so are his Miami Hurricanes. Two days after scoring a season-high 31 points in an 84-78 overtime win at Florida State, Hite scored a game-high 25 points and equaled a career best with seven 3-pointers to lead Miami (13-8, 5-3) to a 78-69 Atlantic Coast Conference win over Wake Forest (12-9, 1-7). "He's playing at an unbelievable level," Miami coach Frank Haith said. "He's taken a lot of stuff about not playing big in big games, but he's our most consistent player this season. He's in a tremendous flow right now." "I'm just in a zone right now," Hite said. Hite scored 17 of his 25 points in the second half, which saw Miami mount a 23-6 run after falling behind 41-35 in the first 1:17. Hite connected on three consecutive 3-pointers, with the last one giving the Hurricanes a 49-43 lead with 15:24 remaining. "Man, they made some tough shots," said Justin Gray, who led Wake Forest with 20 points but scored only three in the second half. "The three-pointers can impact the game. Especially when you give them up in a row." Miami's lead swelled to 11 points after a runner by Denis Clemente made it 58-47 at 9:33. Wake Forest pulled to within seven points twice, including 60-53 after a basket by Eric Williams at 7:00. But Hite responded by drilling his fifth 3-pointer of the game from the left corner just 17 seconds later, and a runner by Guillermo Diaz put Miami up 65-53 at 6:43. Wake Forest never got closer than nine points after that. "We didn't respond back," Wake Forest coach Skip Prosser said. "We had a run to start the half, they had a run back, and it was up to us to make a run back at them. We didn't have the wherewithal to do that." "Obviously, it's a great win for us," Haith said. "I just think we're playing with good poise, good patience." Miami shot 52.1 percent from the field for the game, including 60.9 percent in the second half. Hite hit on 7 of 11 field goals, including 7 of 10 3-pointers. Guillermo Diaz and Anthony Harris, the other two members of Miami's vaunted three-guard rotation, scored 18 and 16 points, respectively. "People were making shots tonight," Hite said. "Give them credit, they made some tough shots," Prosser said. "We played three or four different defenses, but at the end of the day, we didn't have an answer for the way they shot the ball." The loss marked the fourth straight and seventh in the past eight games for the Demon Deacons, who are in sole possession of last place in the ACC. "It's not like we're getting blown out by forty or anything like that," Gray said. "We're right there in the game. We've just got to get those guys on the ship and toughen those games out."

statistics.name: points
statistics.description: The number of points scored.

statistics.name: fieldGoals
statistics.description: Field Goal makes and attempts.

statistics.name: freeThrows
statistics.description: Free Throw makes and attempts.

statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.
